Alexandria, I hope I can earn your support for reelection in the June 18th Democratic Primary.

Hi Alexandria Skies, @@2316 and I are hosting @@2446 and @@2432 at my house on Saturday afternoon for a meet and greet. Long term forecast looks beautiful, gonna be a great day to do some local politics! Let me know if you’d like to join!

I would love a space like Reading Terminal except on the West End that features foods, craft, and events from (and for) Alexandria’s  Ethiopian, Afghani, El Salvadorian and other communities. There are pockets of this greatness in strip malls, but having a hub would be awesome.

Years ago I was toasting jalapeño seeds in a skillet to make salsa when Jason arrived. I went to greet him and we started chatting, and then the seeds started to burst in the kitchen. We (and Punky!) started coughing as I realized I had accidentally pepper sprayed the whole condo.
What a great evening at the Empty Bowls Fundraiser for ALIVE!, which does amazing work protecting vulnerable families in Alexandria from hunger and connecting them to vital resources.

Being on City Council means spending a couple months each year reading, considering and asking questions about the hundreds of tables, charts, proposals and projections in these two binders. I love it. One of the best parts of the job.

The entire point of a public radio station operated by a university with a huge endowment should be that it’s insulated from market pressures and able to provide local and national news. WAMU is, from everything I’ve seen, profitable and stable. Why does it need a “strategic shift”?

Of course, we don't know what tomorrow brings. But what I find especially frustrating about thus is that WAMU/DCist is exactly what we might hope for in local journalism; non-profit, community $supported. If we can't make that work well, then I just don't know.

I like “Beyond”. The 2009 film is fine. “Into Darkness” is “Nemesis”-level bad.
Alas….
In my “defense” I was a film minor in college with a concentration in screenwriting and the weekend in question was when I was stuck at my parents’ house for Christmas.

I was so disappointed in “Star Trek Nemesis” when it came out that I rewrote the entire movie in one weekend in 2002.* Does that qualify me as both a geek and nerd?

* - my version still holds up a lot better than the one Paramount released.

I have the Studio Display, and really love it. It's factored into this price comparison. 

The original Macintosh was woefully underpowered for its time. It's predecessor, the Apple Lisa, solved that problem by costing $10k and having 1MB of RAM. The Mac 128k just... didn't solve the problem.

40 years ago, Apple released the first Macintosh. After three hardware platform transitions and the complete replacement of its OS, the Mac has never been more successful, which is kind of incredible. Also, look at how much the tech has advanced for roughly the same cost:

At 11:30pm last night, I realized I hadn't eaten any black-eyed peas yesterday. Fortunately, I was able to get out of bed and cook some real quick. Crisis averted!
Happy New Year, Alexandria!

New Year’s Update: 

Streets are STILL for People!

First Night is in full swing! Music, comedy and two sets of fireworks are happening throughout Old Town. Come down to Market Square for the pre-party leading up to the 6pm Twilight Fireworks. Learn more here: 

www.firstnightalexandria.org

Given that I am interested in sedans, no SUVs or crossovers or hatchbacks, etc, it seems like Hyundai is the only game in town. I’m not on the market for an EV yet, so I hope there’s more options (with CarPlay) by the time I am.

Two days ago, I baked cornbread and a cherry pie. Yesterday, I made turkey, dressing, sweet potatoes, mashed potatoes, gravy and veggies. Today, baked cookies. My kitchen is getting quite a workout this week.
Merry Christmas to everyone in Alexandria and around the world!

As the only openly-gay member of the City Council, I'm honored to have the LGBTQ+ Victory Fund's endorsements as I begin my campaign for re-election. I hope I can earn your support and your vote. Please visit kirkmcpike.com to join my campaign! 4/4
If re-elected, I will continue working to address these challenges, to keep our City on a firm financial footing, and to ensure Alexandria is a City that lives out its progressive values. 3/4

We've taken on our housing crisis, improved transit services, fought flooding, signed historic agreements with our first responder unions and stood up for our progressive values to fight displacement, protect reproductive choice, and defend LGBTQ+ Virginians. 2/4

I'm running for re-election to City Council!

For the past two years, I've been proud to serve on a Council that has taken bold action to address some of our biggest challenges. We have accomplished a great deal, but there's still so much to do. 1/4
Alexandria Democrats are officially reorganized and ready win in 2024!

Having lived across the street from an aquarium with a large number of penguins, I don’t know if it would be the hottest club, but it would be a loud one! Did you know many penguins are nocturnal and loudly bray like donkeys? I didn’t until I rented that apartment in 2004.
Every day, I'm thankful to have the opportunity to serve my amazing community. Happy Thanksgiving, Alexandria! Have a wonderful day!

These perfect ratings will allow the City to borrow at the lowest-possible rates to finance important infrastructure investments.

Alexandria Democrats were out in force today. Thank you to the volunteers who staffed tables at our City's Farmers' Markets!

This afternoon Vice Mayor Jackson and I represented the City Council at the graduation event for this year's Alexandria CERT Program, and the graduation of our City's first-ever Teen CERT class. CERT volunteers are trained to respond in emergencies and help our First Responders!

Today the entire City Council joined Magnus Temple 3 and Magnus Court 100 for the annual wreath laying ceremony honoring the members of the United States Colored Troops who fought to preserve our nation and who are buried at Alexandria National Cemetery.

This doesn’t happen in other countries and it shouldn’t happen here. We need more leaders who are willing to do something about it.

Speaking of music, if you were in Lawrence in the mid-90s you probably heard the local band The Ray-Guns on the radio. Their song “Better Off” is still one of my favorite songs ever. I am slightly paranoid about losing the files I ripped from that album, as I doubt any copies still exist.

It was a good name. Y’all used it for years. The establishment party changed its name every year, but I only remember Unite. I learned a lot watching those elections. Having a base of Greek houses with roughly 100% voter turnout was a huge advantage for Unite.

Like most Greek groups, my fraternity was supportive of Unite in the 1997 student government elections, and it successors in 1998 and 1999, but I had several friends from class involved with Delta Force. I never became directly involved. Where in Texas did you move to?
If you ever came by the TKE house, or were in political science classes, we definitely did!
I was in Lawrence from 1996 to 1999, but never had Gumby’s. Had way too much Pizza Shuttle. That was the cheap pizza my fraternity friends and I would get late at night.

Another Speaker vote appears imminent. When it happens I'll be a tracking it here:

X, formerly known as Twitter, removed the gold “verified” badge from the New York Times’ account amid ongoing complaints about the news organization from owner Elon Musk.

The badge was the only symbol distinguishing the account from impostors amid two major global conflicts in Israel and Ukraine.

The House situation is demonstrating one of the weaknesses of our first-past-the-post Congressional system. In a parliamentary system with proportional representation you form coalitions *after* the election. We form them before voting, and they are intractable and fractious.

This House dysfunction was foreseeable from the moment Republicans won a narrow majority. They could have put the institution first and worked with Democrats to organize an open and functional House, but they've eschewed coalition politics and pushed partisanship at every point.

Second Speaker Vote: 

Hakeem Jeffries: 212 
Jim Jordan: 199 (-1) 
Steve Scalise: 7 
Kevin McCarthy: 5 
Lee Zeldin: 3 
John Boehner: 1 
Byron Donalds: 1 
Tom Emmer: 1 
Mike Garcia: 1 
Kay Granger: 1 
Candice Miller: 1 
Bruce Westerman: 1
Hakeem Jeffries will again receive more votes than Jim Jordan for Speaker of the House.

The House is assembling for a second vote on Jim Jordan's candidacy for Speaker. Here's hoping he falls even further behind!

Follow the vote here as it happens:
I fully support this.

Today is mental health awareness day. What are you doing to check in on your and your loved one’s mental health? Let’s normalize talking about how we are doing. No shame. No stigma. Just strength.

Also, when I was the head of graphic design and layout for my college paper, I went around and around with an advertiser who wanted his ad to read “We sell used CD’s”. I finally convinced him to use the proper “CDs”.
This is a parody of William Safire, but my friends from college and I insist on using proper grammar when saying things like “my husband and I bought two iPhones Pro”.

These sorts of typographical errors are becoming more common and more annoying. You see it all the time with political campaign materials. It should be ’23 not ‘23. The apostrophe points away from the number like it's "scooping" away the characters before it.

The goal of ZFH/HFA is to create a large set of tools the City can use to encourage housing development in ways that further our housing and affordability goals. By creating many different mechanisms we can avoid over reliance on just one approach.

When I ran for Council in 2021, I made it clear that addressing our housing crisis would be one of my top priorities. Last year, I supported Mayor @@2442’s suggestion to set aside the City’s previous piecemeal approach and take this on comprehensively.
